Present Address BALDWINTON, SASK
Pioneer Address W#22-33-22 W.B. MacKenzie P.O., New Canada
Year you came to Saskatchewan 1906
(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? Very few. First four years settlers came about every two weeks. How many of these were bachelor's homes? 16.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? After 1906, we usually met. I had a few more after that.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Sundays.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Every one asked everyone else to visit. When you did visit, you were always asked to stay for a meal, and you accepted what was offered, whether it was meat or vegetables.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Nearly always.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Mostly, it was, "Don't go just now, we're just going to have a cup of tea."

Are the good things we got out quickly, and it was taken for granted that you would stay? If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? Sometimes tea or coffee was the only thing available, but it was the only thing that made through visits comfortable.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to look after the place? Sometimes the whole family - at other times, members went by themselves.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? No.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. Not during the first four years.

I must remember that in this part of the country we were very far from town, Saskatoon 125 miles, Battleford 90 miles, Fall 1908. We had to go outside our home to meet anyone. We had to wait for daylight before we could go home. We managed to have parties in our home about once a week. We had a card party, usually stayed away.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? Very few. First four years settlers were after coming in. Neighbors were few for habitation. Sundays visits were the main job. How many of these were bachelor's homes? The greater number was bachelor's.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? After 1906, we usually met each other once after church service.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? When our child was sick.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Every one asked everyone else to invite. When you did visit, you were always asked to stay for a meal, but you could accept what was offered, accepting no. What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Usually.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Mostly it was, "Don't go yet, we are just going to have a meal."

Are the good things were put out quickly and it was taken for granted that you would eat? If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? In the early days, a cup of tea or coffee was the only drink available - it was the only thing that made through water preferable.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Sometimes the whole family - at other times, members went by themselves.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? No.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. Not during the first four years.

I remember that in this part of the country we were very far from town, Saskatoon 125 miles, Battleford 90 miles. Fall of 1908 within 40 feet, about 45 miles. Spring 1910 Humberley 70 miles, Fall 1910 were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. After the railway arrived parties, dances, occurred almost every year.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? Card parties were held in homes about once a week. Dance was usually called.

Remember going to one dance in 1908 or 9 when there were 30 men and only 3 women. We danced till the women got tired. I'm glad I...

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

Not always, often people did not attend.

How were babies and small children provided for?

Some took them in cloth-baskets. Sometimes fathers covered them with newspapers over them. If baby died at winter time, sometimes found a baby boy among the guests.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

Flat School, the School stable, I put inside barns, the Patten stable. If there wasn't enough room, farmers always found their own办法 to make room.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Solitaire, Crazy Padies, Heath & Co., Rummy

Was there card playing for a prize? Sometimes.

What dances were popular? Square, Waltz, Barn dance.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. Only a Christmas tree.

The majority never danced but the children had nights over the children's special night + showed the entire store. Concert lasted from 2 AM to 2 PM.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.

They younger people liked playing Cards. Others frowned on it. Some would not have it at any price. Those who didn't like Cards usually stayed away.

12. What attempts at formality, or "swank," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? 

There was nothing of this sort in early days. A good many of the houses were one room. Some living room, bedrooms. People who had to drive often did look very much like "Swanking" it.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible.

July 1st 1909. Picnic at Herb P.C. just north of where Russell is now. Mosquitoes very bad. People arrived outdoors with another hanging on the tongue of wagon to help the Open. The mosquitoes landed on the faces.

26. Who organized it? A band played in them was among hanging from the edge poles another hanging on the tongue of wagon to help the Open. The mosquitoes landed on the faces.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? Anybody was welcome, it did not matter how far they had come.

And people were more concerned in having a few cows than anything else.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? Fairly far away around.

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? A few Ball games & games for children. The only Band was the Prairie Band (Hogg) with Mosquitoes hanging the high trees.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? The Women folk always brought Baskets. These were flooded. Landed round. Tea Coffee were provided.

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

We had our Bible - Shakespeare. Samuel's History of England 9 Vols.
To Right the Wrong (Edna Lyall) Down Town (Blackmore) Ben-Hur. Pillar of Fire.
Prince of the House of David. The Throne of Turrid. All of Dickens. The Book of the Baron (Bulwer Lytton) Gods Good Men (Marie Corelli). Dick the Flag to Pretoria.
The Bible by Modern Light (Cunningham Geikie O.O.L.D.) 6 Vols. History of Ireland (Lecky) We Need a Book (Thomson) Colin Clout's Calendar (Grant Allen)

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

From 1906 till Spring of 1908 there was no Mail on P.O., We had to go 90 miles to post our letters & get mail - what happened in Canada during that time is just about a Blank. P.O. established Mackinaw, one mile from us. Mail came by relay from Saskatoon once a week. Postmaster name Ronald, Grand N.E. 15°33'22" W.3. We then subscribed to the Family Herald, Winnipeg Free Press, Farmer Advocate, The Western Producer were the general runs at that date.
